Base:Descriptions.Base:Description:
A small ceremonial mallet made of ebony hardwood, fashioned with a spindle handle, and brushed brass band encircling the hammer's head. This gavel can be used to call for attention, or to punctuate rulings and proclamations. It is a symbol of the authority and right to act officially in the capacity of a chair or presiding officer. It is often struck against a sound block, a striking surface typically also made of hardwood, to enhance its sounding qualities. It is customary to tap the gavel against a lectern or desk to indicate the opening (call to order) and the closing (adjournment) of proceedings. It is also used to keep the meeting itself calm and orderly.
The sound of the gavel strike, being abrupt to start and stop, and clearly audible by all present, serves to sharply define an action in time in a manner clearly perceivable by all, and to endow the action with practical as well as symbolic finality.
The head of the onyx gavel, banded in a ring of brushed brass where the head meets handle, has been carved upon the flat surface of either end with the symbol of the triskele; A motif consisting of a triple spiral exhibiting rotational symmetry.
A small ceremonial mallet commonly made of hardwood, typically fashioned with a handle.

The handle of the gavel has been made in a spindle fashion; Tapered center twisting and broadening at the base of the handle, where it connects to the head, and a rounded point at the end of the handle.
